1. Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis:

• Frame 1:  
  – Large orange “Detour Ahead” signs appear on the right; there is also a barricade straight ahead blocking the lane, with an orange arrow sign pointing left (labeled “Detour Road”).  
  – A “Stop” sign is on the right corner.  

• Frame 2:  
  – The view is clearer that the road straight ahead is fully closed by orange barriers.  
  – The same orange arrow sign on the barricade points left, indicating a detour.  

• Frame 3:  
  – The bike‐lane symbol is visible, but the lane itself is blocked just beyond it.  
  – The “Detour Road” sign (arrow pointing left) is more prominent, reaffirming that through‐traffic is diverted left.  

• Frame 4:  
  – The “Stop” sign is more clearly visible on the right side, where the intersection meets a cross street.  
  – A “One Way” sign is also present, its arrow pointing to the left—further evidence that any turn onto this cross street must be left.  

• Frame 5:  
  – The barricades completely seal off the straight path.  
  – The left‐pointing “Detour → Road” sign and “One Way [←]” confirm that the only available (and legal) path is left.  

2. Contextual Reasoning:

Since forward travel is blocked and there is a detour arrow pointing left, plus the cross street is apparently one‐way to the left (as indicated by the “One Way” sign), ego must turn left at the intersection.  

3. Match to Answer Choices:

• A. Turn left.  
  – Matches all the signage and the detour/one‐way requirements.

• B. Go straight.  
  – Not possible; the barricade blocks the road and signage clearly forbids going straight.

• C. Turn right.  
  – Not supported by the “One Way” arrow pointing left and the detour that directs traffic left.

• D. Reverse.  
  – No indication that reversing is needed or required; the detour directs a left turn.

4. Provide the Best Answer:

<answer>A</answer>
